description: Borrowed from French idéologie, from idéo- +‎ -logie (equivalent to English ideo- +‎ -logy). Coined 1796 by Antoine Destutt de Tracy. Modern sense of “doctrine” attributed to use of related idéologue (“ideologue”) by Napoleon Bonaparte as a term of abuse towards political opponents in early 1800s.

entries.meaning: Doctrine, philosophy, body of beliefs or principles belonging to an individual or group.
examples: A dictatorship bans things, that do not conform to its ideology, to secure its reign.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The study of the origin and nature of ideas.
